titlestmt.titleproper: Edwin Weyburn and Richard La Barre Goodwin papers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-06-15 10:42:54 -0400.

did.unittitle: Edwin Weyburn and Richard La Barre Goodwin papers

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Archives of American art does not own the original papers. Use is limited to the microfilm copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebook, ca. 1830-1845, kept by Edwin Weyburn Goodwin listing portraits painted, the date, and payment received for each work; a few letters from Richard La Barre Goodwin which give an account of his service in the Civil War; photographs of Richard La Barre Goodwin's paintings; and correspondence of his daughter, Claribel Goodwin, relative to contemporary exhibitions of his work.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: 35mm microfilm reel N60-1 available at Archives of American Art offices and through interlibrary loan.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Originals returned to lender, Claribel Goodwin, after microfilming.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edwin Weyburn Goodwin was an itinerant miniature and portrait painter in upstate New York. During his fifteen year career, ca. 1830-1845, he painted approximately 800 portraits. His son, Richard La Barre Goodwin, was a landscape, portrait and still-life painter; best known as a painter of fish and game. Until ca. 1880, Richard La Barre Goodwin, like his father, was an itinerant painter of portraits in upstate New York.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The lender, Miss Claribel Goodwin, is the granddaughter of Edwin Weyburn Goodwin and daughter of Richard La Barre Goodwin.

odd.head: Other Title
odd.p: Richard La Barre Goodwin papers (microfilm title)
